elements.text:
The graphics workspace is where you make the
sprites for your cartridges. Like the other
editor workspaces there is a hamburger menu at
the top left and file tabs along the top of the
toolbar.

In the center of the page is the sprite editor, 
this is where you draw any sprites for your
programs. At the bottom left of the screen you
can see the current pixel coordinates local to
the sprite your mouse is at. The origin is at
the top left of the sprite (Not the bottom left
like in other software).

On the right side of the workspace is the 
graphics menu, it contains a wide variety
of tools to draw your sprites with.

At the top of the side bar is the color palette.
The first tab (not focused by default) shows all
64 colors in index order. The other tab is a
palette organized to show gradients better, this
only shows the 32 default colors.

In each tab you can click a color to select it.

Below the palette is the toolbar, with tools
to edit the sprite you have selected.

Pen
Sets the pixel you are hovering over to the
selected color. Right-clicking will set the
currently selected color to the same color
that you are hovering over in the editor.

Brush
Draws with the size selected, you can also
select a pattern below the toolbar whenever
this tool is selected.

Line
Allows easily drawing pixelated lines from
one point to another.

Rectangle
Allows easily drawing pixelated rectangles
from corner to corner. You can hold control
to make it filled.

Circle
Allows easily drawing pixelated circles from
corner to corner. You can hold control to make
it filled.

Fill bucket
Clicking will fill in whatever was clicked
with the selected color.
Stamp

Allows for stamping down copies of whatever
is currently on your clipboard, you can copy
a sprite with CTRL-C. You can also copy the
current selected area.

Selection
Allows you to select a region on the sprite
you are editing, clicking and dragging from
corner to corner.

Pan
Allows you to move the viewport of the sprite
you are editing. You can also use the spacebar
to activate this tool without clicking it.

Lastly is the sprite panel. This shows a grid
your sprites, with four tabs (256 sprites per
file). Above this you can see a preview of the
sprite you have selected. Directly next to the
preview are two fields with integers in them
(By default they are both 16), this controls
the size (in pixels) of the sprite you have
selected. There is a small padlock icon in the
middle, if it is locked then the ratio of the
sprite will be retained when resizing it.

For a sprite's size to change you'll need to
press enter.

To the right of the sprite size you can edit the
sprite flags, these are allow you to store an
extra byte of data in each sprite. You do this
by clicking on and off the little lights. These
don't do anything by default, but are useful for
making sprites behave differently.

A good use case of these sprite flags is to
decide which sprites collide with the player.
